Award.AwardTitle: Biotic inventory and evolution of the terrestrial vertebrate fauna of nuclear Central America
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will survey and document the biodiversity of amphibian, reptile, bird and small mammal faunas in Nuclear Central America, defined as the region between the Isthmus of Tehuantepec in Mexico and the Nicaraguan depression. Due to its location at the boundary of several tectonic plates, this region is extraordinarily varied in its topography, including volcanic and uplifted highland areas of varying age and geological origin. The continuing recent reports of many new species from the region demonstrates that much of the diversity of the region remains to be described. Unfortunately, this part of Central America has suffered extensive deforestation. This research project aims to generate extensive data on species distributions and diversity that can be used both to test evolutionary hypotheses and to guide conservation actions for the region.

The project is a collaboration between the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, University of California, the Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, the Universidad de San Carlos de Guatemala, the Zamorano Pan-American Agricultural School in Honduras, and the Universidad Nacional Autónoma de Nicaragua. This project will include training of a postdoctoral student, as well as training and exchange of several undergraduates from the University of California and the four Central American universities mentioned above.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were to improve our knowledge of the vertebrate biodiversity of Nuclear Central America (Chiapas, Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua) through survey expeditions conducted in collaboration with institutions in these countries. We used the specimens, tissue samples and other data from these expeditions not only to enhance museum collections, but also to improve our understanding of the factors that have led to the high biodiversity of the region. This region sits at the intersection of multiple geological plates, resulting in complex topography. We surveyed sites across mountain ranges of different ages, connectivity, and geological origin, to begin to understand the role of various processes in generating species diversity of terrestrial vertebrates, ultimately helping to explain the causes of high tropical biodiversity. The vertebrate biodiversity of Nuclear Central America is relatively poorly known, and another goal of this project was the discovery and description of new species of terrestrial vertebrates. We also aimed to improve distributional knowledge of vertebrates through survey work, especially in areas where no data on species assemblages exist. We aimed to use these data to identify priority areas for conservation so that management decisions can be made using the best available distributional data while also accounting for the evolutionary history of the region’s fauna.

We added 4331 vouchered specimens (together with associated tissues and metadata) from Nuclear Central America to museum collections in the United States, Mexico and Guatemala. Our survey work and molecular and morphological analyses have resulted in the description of 12 salamander species and one snake and one mouse species, with several further species descriptions forthcoming. Several important range extensions have also been documented. For example, we can report the first discovery of Bradytriton silus outside its previously exceedingly tiny geographical range in northwest Guatemala far to the northeast in extreme northern Chiapas, an especially significant discovery for a species listed as Critically Endangered. Our collections also produced some museum specimens of exceedingly high value, including species known only from one individual with no tissue samples available, enabling their inclusion in phylogenetic analyses. We have described one new small mammal species and removed from synonymy three species of small mammal. We have identified several additional new species of small mammals that still await description. We have published the first records of two bat species from Guatemala: Micronycteris minuta and Carollia castanea. We have published an important range extension of the bird Mountain Elaenia into Mexico, a new country record. Phylogeographic analyses of five bird lineages have uncovered considerable genetic diversity and structure in three of these species. Our phylogeographic analyses have helped us to understand how processes of population- and species divergence have differed across elevations. We found that while major biogeographic barriers (e.g., dry valleys caused by faults) seem to have played an important role in the evolution of a clade of montane vertebrates, the divergence of lowland species coincides poorly with these same barriers. Our results have been disseminated in 22 peer-reviewed publications to date. We partnered with local NGOs where our survey work played a central role in the designation of two forests as new protected areas by the government of Guatemala.

A final key component of this project was student training, both in the US and at participating institutions in Central America, and capacity building at foreign institutions. We conducted research jointly with our collaborators in Mexico and Central America to work across taxonomic groups to gain a more comprehensive understanding of biological processes that have affected the evolution of the terrestrial fauna. As part of this project, we have trained 22 undergraduate researchers (10 from UC Berkeley, 12 from Central America), many of whom plan to pursue advanced degrees in biology. The Central American students trained as part of this project have valuable skills for biodiversity-related work in their home countries (Mexico, Guatemala), and several have learned techniques such as molecular lab methods that they can now impart to their colleagues. We have also trained several graduate students from the US, Mexico, and Guatemala, four of which now hold faculty positions in their home countries. This project has allowed a postdoctoral researcher to gain experience in the fields of programming and use of next-generation sequence data, expanding the types of projects that he is capable of doing. He recently started a faculty position.
